awd_abstract_narration:
Contemporary scientific discovery depends upon easy access to data, and associated sophisticated tools and applications, to enable consequential research and education.  Researchers who once worked in local, isolated laboratories now routinely collaborate on a global scale.  Technological advances in data analysis techniques and cloud computing have enabled numerous science research communities to advance and accelerate scientific discovery.  The Cloud-Ecosystem in a Box (CEB) project creates a community of practice among minority serving institutions. CEB assists in training investigators and students in diverse communities to migrate their scientific research activities to both National Science Foundation (NSF)-supported experimental cloud computing research testbeds, and to private sector cloud computing systems.  This project will train diverse communities in rich and complex emerging sources of data and new advances in data analysis techniques, expanding the nation's information technology workforce.

CEB will develop a collaborative community, initially composed of 10 institutions, which will generate conceptual and methodological innovations in cloud computing research leveraging NSF funded cloud and industry ecosystems. The activity will also create a means of: 1) enabling and fostering innovative change within cloud computing training; 2) sharing knowledge and resources as innovation takes place; 3) enabling heightened outreach to diverse communities to build a vibrant pipeline for students aspiring to enter information technology professions; and 4) strengthen the ability to evaluate new research strategies leveraging these resources.

This award reflects NSF's statutory mission and has been deemed worthy of support through evaluation using the Foundation's intellectual merit and broader impacts review criteria.
org_dir_long_name: Directorate for Computer and Information Science and Engineering

por.por_cntn:
Project Outcomes Report

Award Title: Cloud Ecosystem in Box 

Director/PI: Brenton Stewart 

Federal Award ID: 1842679

Project Portal: Cloudsforall.org

Enhancing Research Capacity and Opportunity:

Researchers are confronted with a flood of digital data which has become a fundamental challenge in  21st century research. New techniques, tools, and strategies for dealing with massive datasets, whether they consist of vast numbers of base-pair sequences, or terabytes of data from astronomical, bioinformatics, mathematics, and computer and information sciences presents an opportunity to establish a 'fourth paradigm' of scientific discovery, but the task is not easy. Cloud computing has changed scientific research for many communities, although some institutions have been left on the sidelines of this new computing revolution. Minority serving institutions (MSIs) represent a significant source of untaped research potential, because of their lack of utilization of cloud computing for computational and storage activities in their research activities. 

Cloud Ecosystem in Box (CEB) assists MSIs in leveraging cloud computing resources. CEB built the next generation of scaffolding for MSIs via cloud computing which provides services such as Microsoft, Amazon Web Services, Google Cloud Computing, and Oracle. The project was carried out by partnership between computer and social/information scientists, that allowed the team to build a hub that handled automated data ingesting, dynamic research communities alongside distinctive educational materials crafted to support this distinctive group of researchers. 

New platform for humans and machines to work in concert in data movement to the cloud: 

CEB provided an innovative platform to guide researchers into cloud computing ecosystems. This was achieved by combining human and machine learning efforts in real-time to create a system capable of automatically ingesting diverse research data types and migrating them into the cloud. This allows CEB to support large scale file transfers, while accommodating simultaneous, complex user behavior. As a result, CEB algorithms provide a plug-and-play architecture. 

Improving MSI research performance: 

The project added to the understanding of virtual organizational design, from the perspective of socio technical structures and processes involved in the movement of large datasets, migrating research, and training in cloud computing.  This contributed to our understanding, and refinement of the conceptual framework in the relationships between organizational structure, work design, and deployed cyberinfrastructure technologies. Additionally, CEB assisted MSI institutions' leaders in understanding the practical value of faculty research activities, which could lead to novel implementations of cloud computing resources at MSIs in other areas of science, engineering research and education. The early results of CEB have indicated that researchers and project leaders are leveraging CEB training/resources to identify appropriate project structures and best practices to employ research in the cloud computing environment.  

Improving learning opportunities at MSIs:

CEB has expanded MSIs researchers' exposure to the public in scientific research that directly advances outreach via formal and informal learning opportunities on their respective campuses. These activities enabled researchers to create and disseminate research insights to a wider audience; as well as increase faculty, and student exposure to large-scale data collection, and provide opportunities to leverage public interest in other aspects of scientific knowledge production, particularly members of minority communities. CEB allowed MSIs faculty research activities to contribute to the education of a wider group of doctoral, masters and undergraduate students who will learn about research, particularly its  practical value to their communities, institutions and futures. 

Summary: 

Project CEB echoes both Louisiana State University and the School of Library & Information Sciences' aim to foster inclusive and equitable research and learning environments. 

 


Last Modified: 01/24/2022
Modified by: Brenton Stewart
